Posts.Content: A DRE (Rectal examination) then a PSA. My urologist a Mr Solomon in the UK did say that after a rectal examination he wanted the PSA done at least 8 days later as the examination raises the PSA substantially. Having just been through the prostate scare myself, I'm a newbie with what they tell me is Prostatitis.. Another notable thing he said was my PSA at 5.10 and a enlarged prostate he wasn't worried, however If my prostate was normal or smaller with a 5.10 reading that would cause him concern. Barry
Posts.Signature: Diagnosed stage 3 March 011 Radical resection April 011 Restaged 2b April 011. 12/09 Colonoscopy clear but picked up hospital infection. Aorta & femoral arteries occluded. Clot buster drugs put me in ICU with internal bleeding. 9 blood units later they got it under control. Aortobifemoral surgery 5th May. yughh. PET scan indicates clear DEXA bone scan clear 13/5 CT showed "unknown" but no concern from docs. Inguinal lymph nodes and severe groin pain. Ultrasound and MRI show no nasties. Pheww Groin pain and enlarged lymph nodes still there. October -still the same pains but under semi control. Additional chest CT scan ordered for 11th November prior to surgery. Sinus surgery done and dusted. July 2014 PSA at 5.10. 2months of antibiotics in case of UTI, jan 2015 PSA at 7.20, 23/08 now 8.2, current 8.1 Prostate Cancer confirmed Gleason 3+Marginal 4. Active surveillance continues. PET CT Aug 2017 indicated lung nodule changes CT Guided biopsy 7/09 November 1 Vats Wedge section pathology Glomulated previous infection no Cancer. Not all's rosy in the garden, but see following. Stop grumbling Baz, your still alive and kicking so far. Age and illness doesn't define who we are, but more what we are able to do. Motto Do what I love doing, when I can until I can't. and dodging bullets in the meanwhile, too many bullets at moment.

Posts.Title: Raising Awareness For Prostate Cancer Research

Posts.Content: I can't comment much as I'm at the starting gate with a rise in PSA from 5.10 to 7.20 in 6 months. The urology team are taking a different route for me, not rushing into a biopsy, but T3 MRI scan in March and another PSA test in 3 months. My hospital has told me with their new T3 scanner they use this as a first line rather than a invasive biopsy. Who knows as they are taking a very relaxed approach and not rushing into any invasive procedure. Like yourself we shall have to see what happens. In the meantime good luck. Barry

Posts.Title: Concerned about upcoming biopsy

Posts.Content: I Can’t speak for US insurance but as far as UK and Europe (Cant see there will be much difference to be honest) anyone taking out travel insurance ONE HAS to DECLARE every single condition even high BP as an example. For cancer and I mean any cancer remembering you have to declare every medical condition, if one is given the option of covering a particular condition they load the premium or refuse to cover that element. For cancer there is also (with every UK insurance company and this includes US insurers registered in the U.K. or Europe) a exclusion for 5 years NED is the norm and at 5 NED it remains up to the insurer whether they will cover or not. Note, Any and I mean ANY medical condition where one has received treatment in the previous year including prescription medications NOT DECLARED at the time of making a declaration INVALIDATES you’re insurance if you make a claim for any injury or necessary treatment whilst on holiday.PERIOD. Having since diagnosis in 2010 had to go through the same process every year, I can tell you it’s a nightmare as one has to be totally open and honest. Otherwise. Barry

AgeInfo.Phrase: is the norm and at 5 NED it remains up to

Posts.Title: Travel insurance

Posts.Content: Brave, Wish it was the same here in Blighty. We were through our bank with no problems except no cover for CRC. Here believe me, omit a single medical condition make a claim for anything and if they find out, and they do as the insurance company check with your doctor for any pre conditions. Anything remotely that can be associated with a pre condition and I do mean anything the claim is denied as many many have found to their cost not to mention they have been prosecuted for making a fraudulent claim. Happy travelling. Barry

Having since diagnosis in 2010 had to go through the same process every year, I can tell you it’s a nightmare as one has to be totally open and honest. Otherwise. Barry

Posts.Title: Surgery Tomorrow

Posts.Content: So, had my biopsy done today, frankly not too bad at all some 6 hours post procedure. My hospital (Queen Alexandra at Portsmouth) have just introduced a new procedure which I found interesting. Their new software programme allows them to overlay the T3 MRI results over the real time ultrasound during the biopsy so there is no guesswork as they can now specifically target the location (s) of interest identified by the T3 MRI scan. This was the first day they have used this technique during during a template biopsy. So I had both targetted as well as saturation with 42 cores taken. The URO wanted to do both so that with the aid of the new software he had a complete map of my prostate, explaining this would provide them with a complete picture. All in all no where near as bad as I imagined, again it was a general anaesthic so knew nothing. Whole procedure took 50 minutes with only slight bleeding and after two pees urine is completely clear. Results in 3 weeks. Barry

No way of checking but I Beleive him. Question, You guys keep mentioning fusion biopsy, is this the same asI described. ?. You all keep healthy. Barry

Posts.Title: Biopsy Completed today

Posts.Content: My two pennies worth. I was diagnosed Gleason 6 back in April after a fusion 32 core biopsy. i discussed options with my Uro, all options were offerred including radical prostactemy and after a long discussion we agreed AS was the best option at the time. I am on 3 monthly PSA testing and IF nothing changes a further fusion biopsy again in April next year. I was offerred a second opinion should I wish, but my guy according to my GP's is the very best and as the slides are not reviewed by him but a team my mind is at ease. I admit I am more than comfortable with the AS regime as I have wonderful GP's and a very proactive Urology Department at my hospital. Im not suggesting my attitude will suit all but, so far it has worked for me and I thankfully don't have anxiety issues. In fact I'm so comfortable with it that we are definately skiing again in January. As my Uro Mr.Lemke Solomon jokingly said, I wouldn't dare interfere with your plans to get on your ski's again. That works for me. Good luck with whatever option you choose, it's as always a difficult decision, yet in the UK as we have our National Health Service money or insurance is not a consideration. Barry

Posts.Content: So, had my biopsy done today, frankly not too bad at all some 6 hours post procedure. My hospital (Queen Alexandra at Portsmouth) have just introduced a new procedure which I found interesting. Their new software programme allows them to overlay the T3 MRI results over the real time ultrasound during the biopsy so there is no guesswork as they can now specifically target the location (s) of interest identified by the T3 MRI scan. This was the first day they have used this technique during during a template biopsy. So I had both targetted as well as saturation with 42 cores taken. The URO wanted to do both so that with the aid of the new software he had a complete map of my prostate, explaining this would provide them with a complete picture. All in all no where near as bad as I imagined, again it was a general anaesthic so knew nothing. Whole procedure took 50 minutes with only slight bleeding and after two pees urine is completely clear. Results in 3 weeks. Barry
Posts.Signature: Diagnosed stage 3 March 011 Radical resection April 011 Restaged 2b April 011. 12/09 Colonoscopy clear but picked up hospital infection. Aorta & femoral arteries occluded. Clot buster drugs put me in ICU with internal bleeding. 9 blood units later they got it under control. Aortobifemoral surgery 5th May. yughh. PET scan indicates clear DEXA bone scan clear 13/5 CT showed "unknown" but no concern from docs. Inguinal lymph nodes and severe groin pain. Ultrasound and MRI show no nasties. Pheww Groin pain and enlarged lymph nodes still there. October -still the same pains but under semi control. Additional chest CT scan ordered for 11th November prior to surgery. Sinus surgery done and dusted. July 2014 PSA at 5.10. 2months of antibiotics in case of UTI, jan 2015 PSA at 7.20, 23/08 now 8.2, current 8.1 Prostate Cancer confirmed Gleason 3+Marginal 4. Active surveillance continues. PET CT Aug 2017 indicated lung nodule changes CT Guided biopsy 7/09 November 1 Vats Wedge section pathology Glomulated previous infection no Cancer. Not all's rosy in the garden, but see following. Stop grumbling Baz, your still alive and kicking so far. Age and illness doesn't define who we are, but more what we are able to do. Motto Do what I love doing, when I can until I can't. and dodging bullets in the meanwhile, too many bullets at moment.
Posts.Title: Biopsy Completed today

Posts.Content: My two pennies worth. I was diagnosed Gleason 6 back in April after a fusion 32 core biopsy. i discussed options with my Uro, all options were offerred including radical prostactemy and after a long discussion we agreed AS was the best option at the time. I am on 3 monthly PSA testing and IF nothing changes a further fusion biopsy again in April next year. I was offerred a second opinion should I wish, but my guy according to my GP's is the very best and as the slides are not reviewed by him but a team my mind is at ease. I admit I am more than comfortable with the AS regime as I have wonderful GP's and a very proactive Urology Department at my hospital. Im not suggesting my attitude will suit all but, so far it has worked for me and I thankfully don't have anxiety issues. In fact I'm so comfortable with it that we are definately skiing again in January. As my Uro Mr.Lemke Solomon jokingly said, I wouldn't dare interfere with your plans to get on your ski's again. That works for me. Good luck with whatever option you choose, it's as always a difficult decision, yet in the UK as we have our National Health Service money or insurance is not a consideration. Barry

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed - Gleason 6

Posts.Content: John, Sorry your having these issues. I'm on the CRC forum, yet in the same situation as yourself with my template biopsy being done on the 6th May after elevated PSA of 7.20. Also same as yourself had no symptoms and no weight loss. I would suggest that there is a good possibility your weight loss could be due to anxiety as the pounds do fall off with anxiety as your metabolism accelerates dramatically. Worrying is a natural reaction but try and get things onto a even keel and not let your thoughts control you. Easier said than done I admit, but having been through cancer once before, it tends to educate one that worrying over something we have zero control over is counter productive. What I can't control I leave it to the experts. But again what do I know as I'm not a medical doctor but possibly talk to him /her on prescribing some medication to help with the anxiety. Possibly a call into your doc may provide you with a reliable answer and some solution to your anxiety. When is your biopsy date ?. Take care and good luck with the biopsy. Barry

Posts.Title: Awaiting Biopsy

Posts.Content: The NHS England have published the possible incidence of prostate cancer in African, Carribean ethnicity is 4 times higher than white Caucasian. Ditto is stated in Prostate Cancer UK, MacMillan cancer support. cancer.org.uk. It is widely and freely available on any official government or reputable websites.

Posts.Title: Is it true that black men are more likely to get prostate cancer?

Posts.Content: Hearts, Prostatitis is definately ruled out as my doc said when I questioned him on this, he said and I quote "If it was prostatitis when I pressed on your prostate you would have jumped off the couch". We can rule out Urinary tract infection Sex not applicable No I didn't ride my bike to the docs and there is a darn steep hill on the way. He also ruled out any increases after the other 2 DRE's I've had in the last 2 weeks. Gradually rising PSA from 2009 till current 5.1 missing out 011 and 012 due to the 2 other surgeries I had. Barry

Posts.Title: Need advice please

Posts.Content: Thanks guys, I knew I would get the best knowledge and advice available. Mikla, Several days between the DRE and the test. I understand 5.1 is on the low reference end of the scale, but since I didn't have a PSA in 2010 or 2011 due to the other major surgeries, this is the 1st. Doctor used this 5.1 value as a base reference and wants a bone and PSA test this time around. So I need to arrange these in the next few days. As far as possible infection 4 weeks ago they put me on Doxycycline as I had painfully enlarged Inguinal lymph nodes and they wanted to rule out any infection. They then put me on Amoxcillin 1500 mg day as a chaser to again knock out possible infection but this was for those lymph nodes. What is concerning me is that in the last several weeks I got a definate CRC recurrence which was then retracted it was "now" a constriction at the colon join OR adhesions. Then the painful lymph nodes erupted with no diagnosis. Then the pain between the legs horrendous on one occasion, then pelvic pain and after a further week a dull ache both side i elbow rib cage both sides so they speculated it may be kidneys. Obviously there are some mixed message symptoms going on which also may be baffling them. I'm not panicking at all, I just need to know answers as to what is going on and a heads up from you guys on what to look out for and what questions I should put to my docs. This is why these forums are so important, so many knowledgeable people and experience one can't put a value on. Thanks again Baz

Posts.Title: Need advice please

Posts.Content: Firstly a explanation. I know the ins and outs of Colorectal Cancer, but I'm a complete novice at this prostate stuff. Have been having more than a few problems lately, they thought I had a CRC recurrence then dismissed it, then brought it back as a possibility. Then enlarged Inguinal lymph nodes which are still under investigation so the jury's out on this until,after a MRI then an ultrasound on the 6th and 12 th May. Meanwhile I started getting pains between my legs with a ache around my pelvis and lower back in the area of both kidneys. Have had 3 DRE's in the last 2 weeks, on all occasions the findings were normal with no lumps or bumps or irregularities. 2009 my PSA was < 2 I missed 2010 and 2011 2012 < 3 2013 < 4 2014 5.1 MY GP decided that as I hadn't had a PSA in the last 2 years it would be a good thing. Heyho he called this afternoon at 3.30 to say my PSA was elevated at 5.1 which for my age 69 put me in the investigation envelope. No problem with urination, no problem with start up or stream but a few run offs when stopping. They have a planned MRI of my lower back on 6th and because of the enlarged lymph nodes a ultrasound of the groin and pelvis on 12th May. I'm not jumping to PC at this stage, but do need a heads up on what are the key indicators and what should I be looking out for. Sounds daft I know but as a Supermod on the CRC forum,I've come to the one place where I know there is a wealth of Prostate knowledge. Question at 69 years old does 5.1 ring alarm bells with you guys. And What should I be looking out for and what questions should I fire at my GP. As I said if it was CRC I could answer my own questions but the possibility of PC is a new thing for me. Thanks guys for any input you can give. Barry

Posts.Title: Merry Christmas

Posts.Content: I can only add to our knowledgable members who replied my two cents for what it's worth. Been through the typical AS regime for the last 32 months having had a T3 MRI, a saturated biopsy of plus 30 cores. 18 month follow up TRUS of 14 cores which except for 1 which showed marginal score of 4. All the remainder 3+3 so I'm both relaxed with continuing AS. the key wording from the URO was It will not shorten your life. Good luck Barry

Posts.Signature: Diagnosed stage 3 March 011 Radical resection April 011 Restaged 2b April 011. 12/09 Colonoscopy clear but picked up hospital infection. Aorta & femoral arteries occluded. Clot buster drugs put me in ICU with internal bleeding. 9 blood units later they got it under control. Aortobifemoral surgery 5th May. yughh. PET scan indicates clear DEXA bone scan clear 13/5 CT showed "unknown" but no concern from docs. Inguinal lymph nodes and severe groin pain. Ultrasound and MRI show no nasties. Pheww Groin pain and enlarged lymph nodes still there. October -still the same pains but under semi control. Additional chest CT scan ordered for 11th November prior to surgery. Sinus surgery done and dusted. July 2014 PSA at 5.10. 2months of antibiotics in case of UTI, jan 2015 PSA at 7.20, 23/08 now 8.2, current 8.1 Prostate Cancer confirmed Gleason 3+Marginal 4. Active surveillance continues. PET CT Aug 2017 indicated lung nodule changes CT Guided biopsy 7/09 November 1 Vats Wedge section pathology Glomulated previous infection no Cancer. Not all's rosy in the garden, but see following. Stop grumbling Baz, your still alive and kicking so far. Age and illness doesn't define who we are, but more what we are able to do. Motto Do what I love doing, when I can until I can't. and dodging bullets in the meanwhile, too many bullets at moment.

Posts.Title: Wolfgang

Posts.Content: In the UK the gold standard now is the T3 MRI. My case June 2014 PSA of 5.10 slightly elevated for my age, January 2015 up to 7.2. March 2015 T3 MRI showed left lobe is cancer. Now they are planning a 38 core template biopsy and after that they will decide what they are going to do with me. However all the way through the urology consultant has offered the words "no rush" , like you it's a wait and see game. Barry

Posts.Title: Off Topic: Virtual Colonoscopy

Posts.Content: Being a relative newbie myself to prostate cancer after having colon cancer, the only difference between yourself and me is 12.9% one core mine being 5%. Similar prostate size at double, yet after lengthy discussions with my eminent urologist we both agreed active surveillance was the way to go. After 31 months a further biopsy confirmed a borderline 4 in one core (3+4 ish) to continue with AS. The key phrase used was "it will most definitely not shorten you're life". So rather than rush in with any of the interventions, surgery, radiotherapy, seeds, HT we jointly elected to continue AS with 3 monthly PSA testing. After a number of major surgeries you can imagine I am more than keen to avoid any further unless absolutely essential. Overall it doesn't materially bother me, although I'm not normally given to anxiety anyway, I don't think about it, it doesn't as yet interfere with my life too much and I'm certainly not obsessed by it. My forum bretheren may disagree as they are far more experienced than myself with PCa yet I am most comfortable with AS and would in my humble opinion suggest anyone in a similar situation to carefully consider all options rather than rush into a surgical or invasive intervention, unless it is absolutely necessary. it all comes down to what the specialists advise and whether one is comfortable with their advice in particular how the diagnosis is accepted by the patient. Good luck and I'm sure you will get numerous responses from our experts once your post is picked up. Barry

Posts.Title: Away we go!

Posts.Content: From a newbie to this forum at least. I had a rising PSA from 5.2 to 7.2 in 6 months, then did a T3 MRI which showed a area of concern. even though I was dreading the thoughts of a biopsy I had a template biopsy, 32 core samples taken under a general anaesthetic which has proved canver. The procedure went like a dream with few effects and only mild soreness. Now I'm waiting until July 1st to see what they are going to do. my two pennies worth is Go have the T3 MRI and if that shows anything have the fusion biopsy as the others have suggested. They are far wiser than I and have given me some excellent advice and support. Bite the bullet and have it done. Good luck Barry

Posts.Title: brachytherapy. as a follow up treatment

Posts.Content: Justin, im somewhat like yourself albeit over a much shorter period and have been on AS now for 3 years with repeated PSA testing on a 6 monthly basis. And I’m considerably older than yourself which may explain why my readings Latest being 8.2 that was 6 months previously. I to have had MRIs and both a Fusion 32 if I recall correctly guided biopsy and 6 months ago a TRUS biopsy from which they regraded from 3+3 to 3+ marginal 4 But was officially told this would not shorten my life and continue with AS. Not being the worrying type I am relaxed and comfortable being on AS protocol, but recently (last couple months) have been experiencing more symptoms of either BPH or PCa symptoms, nothing major just an advancement as I would call them. Allthough Having beencatheterised due to another unrelated surgical complication 2 months ago it could be due to the catheter at least I’m hoping. I add the above not as a life story but to emphasise that as my eminent urologist says he thinks to many menfolk rush into radical treatment to early due to both external pressure as well as internal pressures (I can’t live with PCa ). No doubt I shall have another MRI and possibly interervention IF that is warranted or I decide to take the radical course which I must admit I doubt I shall. My suggestion and that’s all it can be is see what the latest MRI shows and after serious deliberation and in discussion with Your URO go with what is recommended and you are comfortable with. Difficult times I agree. Please keep us updated Barry

AgeInfo.Phrase: MRIs and both a Fusion 32 if I recall correctly guided

Posts.Signature: Diagnosed stage 3 March 011 Radical resection April 011 Restaged 2b April 011. 12/09 Colonoscopy clear but picked up hospital infection. Aorta & femoral arteries occluded. Clot buster drugs put me in ICU with internal bleeding. 9 blood units later they got it under control. Aortobifemoral surgery 5th May. yughh. PET scan indicates clear DEXA bone scan clear 13/5 CT showed "unknown" but no concern from docs. Inguinal lymph nodes and severe groin pain. Ultrasound and MRI show no nasties. Pheww Groin pain and enlarged lymph nodes still there. October -still the same pains but under semi control. Additional chest CT scan ordered for 11th November prior to surgery. Sinus surgery done and dusted. July 2014 PSA at 5.10. 2months of antibiotics in case of UTI, jan 2015 PSA at 7.20, 23/08 now 8.2, current 8.1 Prostate Cancer confirmed Gleason 3+Marginal 4. Active surveillance continues. PET CT Aug 2017 indicated lung nodule changes CT Guided biopsy 7/09 November 1 Vats Wedge section pathology Glomulated previous infection no Cancer. Not all's rosy in the garden, but see following. Stop grumbling Baz, your still alive and kicking so far. Age and illness doesn't define who we are, but more what we are able to do. Posts.Title: What to do? Two different Opinions

Posts.Content: Philbo, I echo Littalex in welcoming you even though I'm on the CRC forum. Enjoyed in part reading your post regarding the wonderful times you had with your good lady countered by reading your in the fourth round of your cancer battle. She sounded to be a truly adventurous and inspiring person, you so blessed to have these memories. Yes, it's amazing how so called friends evaporate during hard and sorrowful times, I've never figured out just why they vanish and I learned not to question their motives. Some that I thought acquaintances stepped up to the plate with immense support and a truly caring attitude. Those that walked away, some ran, now I don't even think about and have no need to forgive, just forget. yes, constant pain alters ones perspective and it is natural to curse and swear and be short tempered, yet you seem to rise to the surface again and regain a positive attitude. Keep up the positives. Best wishes in this long, frustrating journey. Barry

Posts.Title: What to do? Two different Opinions

Posts.Content: Being a relative newbie myself to prostate cancer after having colon cancer, the only difference between yourself and me is 12.9% one core mine being 5%. Similar prostate size at double, yet after lengthy discussions with my eminent urologist we both agreed active surveillance was the way to go. After 31 months a further biopsy confirmed a borderline 4 in one core (3+4 ish) to continue with AS. The key phrase used was "it will most definitely not shorten you're life". So rather than rush in with any of the interventions, surgery, radiotherapy, seeds, HT we jointly elected to continue AS with 3 monthly PSA testing. After a number of major surgeries you can imagine I am more than keen to avoid any further unless absolutely essential. Overall it doesn't materially bother me, although I'm not normally given to anxiety anyway, I don't think about it, it doesn't as yet interfere with my life too much and I'm certainly not obsessed by it. My forum bretheren may disagree as they are far more experienced than myself with PCa yet I am most comfortable with AS and would in my humble opinion suggest anyone in a similar situation to carefully consider all options rather than rush into a surgical or invasive intervention, unless it is absolutely necessary. it all comes down to what the specialists advise and whether one is comfortable with their advice in particular how the diagnosis is accepted by the patient. Good luck and I'm sure you will get numerous responses from our experts once your post is picked up. Barry

Posts.Title: Hey. Need advice.

Posts.Content: Joe, I missed the NOT Normally out of the opening line. I am very serious,what you stated is normal. We don't and can't diagnose you, only a doctor can. You've had a urine test, so I assume that has ruled out a bladder infection. Most men get a burning sensation during urination at some time in their lives, mostly it's dietary related, unless an infection is present. Had you just stated that you had strange sensations permanently in your penis, that's a different matter. But you decided at first to state the obvious, when you drink a lot you pee a lot. How on earth do you expect anyone of us on here to take you seriously when you make such statements. At 22 years old the chances of you having prostate cancer is more than unlikely. As your GP said it could be a multitude of different things totally unrelated to cancer. urine test is not a test for prostate cancer apart from identifying if the are traces of blood in the urine, as it was you say clear, then thats ruled out. The test you may have heard of is a PSA test which is the histology of a blood sample. Seriously, at your age stop thinking you may have prostate cancer. I'm sorry but this is not the place you need to be right now. Address your questions to your GP as she is the only person that can give you a diagnosis. It could be something as simple as a yeast infection. My previous response still stands. Good luck with your GP, I hope you don't tell her in the same way you posted your original as you may just get the same response, a knowing smile and close the door on the way out.

Clot buster drugs put me in ICU with internal bleeding. 9 blood units later they got it under control. Aortobifemoral surgery 5th May. yughh. PET scan indicates clear DEXA bone scan clear 13/5 CT showed "unknown" but no concern from docs. Inguinal lymph nodes and severe groin pain. Ultrasound and MRI show no nasties. Pheww Groin pain and enlarged lymph nodes still there. October -still the same pains but under semi control. Additional chest CT scan ordered for 11th November prior to surgery. Sinus surgery done and dusted. July 2014 PSA at 5.10. 2months of antibiotics in case of UTI, jan 2015 PSA at 7.20, 23/08 now 8.2, current 8.1 Prostate Cancer confirmed Gleason 3+Marginal 4. Active surveillance continues. PET CT Aug 2017 indicated lung nodule changes CT Guided biopsy 7/09 November 1 Vats Wedge section pathology Glomulated previous infection no Cancer. Not all's rosy in the garden, but see following. Stop grumbling Baz, your still alive and kicking so far. Age and illness doesn't define who we are, but more what we are able to do. Motto Do what I love doing, when I can until I can't. and dodging bullets in the meanwhile, too many bullets at moment.

Posts.Title: Hey. Need advice.

Posts.Content: Not advocating one course or the other as I've been on AS now for 2 half years with one fusion template biopsy with no downside and just finished a transrectal 14 core biopsy 3 days before with only a little soreness and infintismal volume of bleeding which has now cleared up. Either I'm lucky or as I prefer to think a very good doc. Not suggesting the procedure is a walk in the park, but the forethoughts are far worse than the procedure itself. For piece of mind or to just get a positive or negative result is worth biting the bullet, for me I'd go with your doc. Barry

Posts.Title: Options aside from a biopsy?

Posts.Content: Joe, Sorry I'm normally as blunt as this, are you taking the p*ss, you've got to be. What do you expect when you drink alcohol. This is a serious forum to provide help and support to cancer sufferers, carers and loved ones. So where do you think you fit into this forum, after stating what you did, you can't go more than 30 minutes if your constantly drinking. Your GP (so it seems your in the UK) has done a urine test, which is clear. When you have a diagnosis of cancer, please come back and we will take you seriously, until then I suggest you cut down the alcohol. Drink more, pee more, drink, less pee less. Until then find a pub you can ask sensible questions in, I'll guarantee that anyone in the pub will give you the same advice.

Posts.Title: Hey. Need advice.

Posts.Content: Joe, I missed the NOT Normally out of the opening line. I am very serious,what you stated is normal. We don't and can't diagnose you, only a doctor can. You've had a urine test, so I assume that has ruled out a bladder infection. Most men get a burning sensation during urination at some time in their lives, mostly it's dietary related, unless an infection is present. Had you just stated that you had strange sensations permanently in your penis, that's a different matter. But you decided at first to state the obvious, when you drink a lot you pee a lot. How on earth do you expect anyone of us on here to take you seriously when you make such statements. At 22 years old the chances of you having prostate cancer is more than unlikely. As your GP said it could be a multitude of different things totally unrelated to cancer. urine test is not a test for prostate cancer apart from identifying if the are traces of blood in the urine, as it was you say clear, then thats ruled out. The test you may have heard of is a PSA test which is the histology of a blood sample. Seriously, at your age stop thinking you may have prostate cancer. I'm sorry but this is not the place you need to be right now. Address your questions to your GP as she is the only person that can give you a diagnosis. It could be something as simple as a yeast infection. My previous response still stands. Good luck with your GP, I hope you don't tell her in the same way you posted your original as you may just get the same response, a knowing smile and close the door on the way out.

Posts.Title: Off Topic but still...

Posts.Content: I'm with Di on this, told 4 weeks before surgery Stop aspirin. Immediately after surgery they put me back on 75mg day. I've also read some interesting stuff that has been published on aspirin and PC together with stroke prevention. Seems in the UK there is now some debate as to the efficacy of aspirin in preventing blood clots, primarily DVT's. Even my GP mentioned this during a recent check up, however was as he said "swayed neither one way or the other". Taking it with other anticoagulants I was told is a definate no no. Barry

Posts.Title: Just wondering if anyone is taking aspirin before or after treatment

Posts.Content: Kent, Understandably your concerned and Chuck being our leading opinion on PCa summed it up more than well. Ive been on active surveillance now for over a year with 2 x 2mm lesions with a core of 5% and my PSA spiked at 7.2 then dropped back to 6. Had the DEXA bone scan 2 years ago now but that was a precaution due to symptoms from previous colon cancer as well as a very nasty upper and lower spinal problem. Indeed they gave me all the options you've been given but added how did I feel about AS. Talking things over with the consultant we both agreed AS was the way to go, a decision I'm very comfortable with to be honest until and unless my PSA rises for which I just had routine PSA test last week and awaiting the results. Being a relative newbie at PCa my forum colleague Chuck gave as well as others gave me great and factual advice which I was pleased to take and surprisingly my forum friends were absolutely correct. Quite reassuring to know that we have such in depth real experience on this forum from people that Know. Barry

Posts.Title: just found out

Posts.Content: It is under NHS Choices where any UK citizen can request their GP to make a referral to the Hopsital of the patients choice, irrespective of location. A word of caution though. I don't know where you are located, but every region has a specialist centre and if that unit can provide treatment in accordance with national standards as per NICE guidelines then a referral to The Royal Marsden or another specialist centre such as Christies may be difficult to get. Anyway your regional centre could well undertake treatment with the support of TRM (Royal Marsden) Where I live my local hospital (Portsmouth) QAH has one of the few Da Vinci robotic units in the UK as well as the surgeons to operate it. Jim Khan, Amjad Parvaiz are the two leaders in robotic prostate surgery as well as about 8 other consultants. May be worth asking your GP on your options. Barry

Posts.Title: Little humor to brighten your day

Posts.Content: Hi, i was always quite philosophical with both invasive biopsies and surgery until the last episodes which have changed my mind significantly. Now I shall not contemplate once but several times before I agree to anymore. In fact the answer irrespective of any potential outcome will be NO and I’m afraid damn the consequences. I have jokingly said up to now, 3 times the hospital has tried to polish me off, now I firmly believe they set it up and then experiment with me. Not really Yet that is how I light heartedly see it. Barry
Posts.Signature: Diagnosed stage 3 March 011 Radical resection April 011 Restaged 2b April 011. 12/09 Colonoscopy clear but picked up hospital infection. Aorta & femoral arteries occluded. Clot buster drugs put me in ICU with internal bleeding. 9 blood units later they got it under control. Aortobifemoral surgery 5th May. yughh. PET scan indicates clear DEXA bone scan clear 13/5 CT showed "unknown" but no concern from docs. Inguinal lymph nodes and severe groin pain. Ultrasound and MRI show no nasties. Pheww Groin pain and enlarged lymph nodes still there. October -still the same pains but under semi control. Additional chest CT scan ordered for 11th November prior to surgery. Sinus surgery done and dusted. July 2014 PSA at 5.10. 2months of antibiotics in case of UTI, jan 2015 PSA at 7.20, 23/08 now 8.2, current 8.1 Prostate Cancer confirmed Gleason 3+Marginal 4. Active surveillance continues. PET CT Aug 2017 indicated lung nodule changes CT Guided biopsy 7/09 November 1 Vats Wedge section pathology Glomulated previous infection no Cancer. Not all's rosy in the garden, but see following. Stop grumbling Baz, your still alive and kicking so far. Age and illness doesn't define who we are, but more what we are able to do. Posts.Title: Antibiotic prophylaxis & complications after prostate biopsies  a review

Posts.Content: Interesting, i must be on the reverse side of this study. Ciprofloxacin 3 days priorto my TRUS resulted in 3 days post TRUS being blue lighted into hospital with major sepsis. 4 days later using a combo of antibiotics it cleared and discharged home. Several months later a VATS Wedge resulted after 3 days being rushed into ICU with yet again Sepsis and acute kidney failure then 3 days in HDU. This time treated with IV Augmentin at what dosage I have no idea and post discharge with 3 weeks tablets of Augmentin at a dosage of 1875 mg day. Im starting to consider whether the first post TRUS sepsis actually cleared my system or whether it is just me. Yet to be hit twice inside 5 months seems to be a little to coincidental unless there are hidden factors I’m unaware of. Albeit a interesting study, yet I’m decidedly concerned as I have another Urology appointment on the 13th of January and IF the consultant recommends another biopsy I shall be taking the high road very quickly. Answer will be a unqualified and resounding NO. Barry

Posts.Title: Antibiotic prophylaxis & complications after prostate biopsies  a review

Posts.Content: Omeprazole generally takes care of any potential bleeds, been there bled profusely, 11 units later they got it stopped. They put me on Omeprazole 40 mg 1 tablet each morning and so far so good. Perhaps he may be able to tolerate NSAIDS if he's on Omeprazole or similar. I've been on Naproxen 500 mg twice a day for my back problem for over a year and up to now haven't had any internal bleeds. Barry

Posts.Title: finger swelling

Posts.Content: Eddie, Welcome to the forum, but sorry you need to find us. Im on the Colon forum and just taking the opportunity to welcome you. I know a little about Prostate cancer, so I'll let our wonderful bunch on the PC forum answer your questions, they are a great team with a wealth of experience and support. From what you say or don't in this case you seem to have recovered well from the PC surgery and it's good news there is confinement and no other involvement. As we are an international organisation covering so many times zones, I'm certain that those on the PC forum will pick up your post when they come online and hopefully give you the answers your looking for. In the meantime stay strong and positive Best wishes Barry

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with pc

Posts.Content: Yes, certainly the UK is the same as Canada. Doctors are not allowed to openly advertise along with consultants. Privately specialist consultants are named on private hospitals surgeons lists together with their speciality and resume. Interestingly consultant surgeons including oncologists are restricted as to what fees they can charge. In my case circa 2010 for a radical hemicolectomy the surgeons bill came to 741 UK pounds for a 5 hr 30 minute operation, consultant anaesthetist charged 450 the remaining 12,000 or so was for the private hospital for 4 days stay. Surgeons charges are set under a BUPA payment scale agreement which most are signed up to. There are I Beleive incentives paid to GP's to favour certain products but as the NHS is tightening its belt more and more generic medicines are being prescribed and given by the pharmacies. Barry

Posts.Title: The "rubber band" stress technique

Posts.Content: Boaz, sounds all too familiar as I have the same symptoms but my PSA was 5.10 which is slightly elevated for my age (70). as you don't say how old you are a PSA of 4.11 could be like myself only slightly elevated. Normally Cipro and Flomax is a 2 month course as a UTI infection is notoriously difficult to treat, hence the length od the antibiotic course and they do a further PSA at week 7 or after finishing the antibiotics. after 7 weeks on Cipro and Flomax my PSA was exactly the same at 5.10. I have a further PSA at 6 months. My urologist did say that I quote '' with a enlarged prostate and your PSA level I am not overly worried. However if your prostate was normal size with a PSA of 5.10 I would be concerned''. Yet the only accurate way to diagnose is a needle biopsy as PSA can be affected by many factors other than PC. Just don't miss your appointment is my advice. best of luck Barry

Posts.Title: PSA Anxiety

Posts.Content: Robert, Sorry to hear this news and hope your fortunes turn around quickly. My understanding, certainly from a UK perspective is that generic medications purchased from a reputable source should have the same efficacy as any Branded medication. I know that many drugs where the patent has expired are manufactured to the same rigorous standard, however that being said, unless one knows or can find out the actual manufacturer then I wouldn't be touching them. In the UK the NHS are purchasing non branded drugs from reputable drug manufacturers in both Europe and India. If the equivalent drug is manufactured by let's say Ranbaxy in India then they are a reputable worldwide manufacturer amd produce at a fraction of the original cost. Disclaimer I don't have any connection with Ranbaxy or any of it's subsidiaries. Im sure if your proposed supplier is reputable then the drugs should be approved either internationally or by the Canadian authorities. Barry

Posts.Title: Merry Christmas!

Posts.Content: I have inherited Glaucoma from my mothers side and it has never been a problem with 3 surgeries I've had. Usually they will ask you or do an eye pressure test and if it's below (if I recall correctly) 25 then no problems. I'm guessing ou use eye drops Xalatan being the worlds most used and this seems certainly in my case to stabilise the eye pressures to circa 18/19. Good luck with your upcoming surgery. Barry

Posts.Title: Glaucoma and robotic surgery.

Posts.Content: To my mind, it is a question of getting expert medical opinion on the circumstances either directly through a peer surgeon or via a lawyer approaching one or more top surgeons and assess the legal risk factor. I'm not one to side with the medical profession as I can only speak about our UK system. Most find that the medical profession tend to close ranks and therefore it is very difficult to get another professional opinion in a litigation case. Maybe in the US things operate differently, I simply don't know. I know after my two surgeries the first thing both surgeons checked for was any signs of a hernia developing. I hope your dad has no more setbacks and continues to recover. Barry

Posts.Title: Stress is over for another 6 months

Posts.Content: Chuck, Bob and Michael, Thanks, I threw that out knowing I didn't have a positive diagnosis yet, however I can't understand without biopsy results why my consultant urologist would open a potential treatment dialogue. This baffled me. My GP got a copy of the MRI report, from what he saw and the interpretation report, he Is firmly convinced the report is accurate. I also had a telephone call last Tuesday from the deputy medical director of my NHS Hospital, this was the call that caused some controversy when I got a letter last year advising I would get a call from the hospital at 13.30 April 7th 2015. She had done a thorough review of my file and was checking on the CRC, vascular etc and my current physical status. She was also surprised that a biopsy hadn't yet been done and would chase this up with a letter to the urology consultant copied to my GP. So as of now I'm in limbo, despite potential treatment options being raised and my GP being convinced. Good news is my GP is on the case and chasing up with the hospital. Isn't life a breeze. Barry

Posts.Title: New battle to commence

Posts.Content: Well folks, No biopsy as yet as still waiting for a date. The consultant said there's no rush on the phone, hmmm but then started to talk about treatment options. Seems they have relied on the T3 MRI results which indicate it is contained but most definately interpreted as cancer. I said "aren't we getting ahead of ourselves as you don't know yet what type or grade it is", response no I Beleive it is far better to discuss options ahead of the biopsy result. I have 2 friends with PCa both were on HT and both had to come off due to dramatic is effects. Any opinion welcome Barry

Posts.Title: New battle to commence

Posts.Content: To my mind, it is a question of getting expert medical opinion on the circumstances either directly through a peer surgeon or via a lawyer approaching one or more top surgeons and assess the legal risk factor. I'm not one to side with the medical profession as I can only speak about our UK system. Most find that the medical profession tend to close ranks and therefore it is very difficult to get another professional opinion in a litigation case. Maybe in the US things operate differently, I simply don't know. I know after my two surgeries the first thing both surgeons checked for was any signs of a hernia developing. I hope your dad has no more setbacks and continues to recover. Barry

Posts.Title: considering sueing surgeon

Posts.Content: I'll not enter into a litigation debate as there are far to many variables. I tend to agree with Spouse, One good thing in using the Internet it the ability to research the qualifications and experience of particular surgeons ( in the UK it's quite easy) , elsewhere I have no idea. I do know that I bothe researched the competency of both the surgeons that operated on me prior to letting them get anywhere near me. Fact, all surgical sites can be prone to herniation, particular abdominal. During pre surgery work up, the risks for every surgical procedure should be explained either verbally and/or written into the official patient acceptance forms. It would be highly unusual for this aspect to have been missed either specifically or generically. I don't think anyone on here can advise a course of action as this will be specific to your dads case. Hoping your dad is getting better and continues to do so. Barry

PET scan indicates clear DEXA bone scan clear 13/5 CT showed "unknown" but no concern from docs. Inguinal lymph nodes and severe groin pain. Ultrasound and MRI show no nasties. Pheww Groin pain and enlarged lymph nodes still there. October -still the same pains but under semi control. Additional chest CT scan ordered for 11th November prior to surgery. Sinus surgery done and dusted. July 2014 PSA at 5.10. 2months of antibiotics in case of UTI, jan 2015 PSA at 7.20, 23/08 now 8.2, current 8.1 Prostate Cancer confirmed Gleason 3+Marginal 4. Active surveillance continues. PET CT Aug 2017 indicated lung nodule changes CT Guided biopsy 7/09 November 1 Vats Wedge section pathology Glomulated previous infection no Cancer. Not all's rosy in the garden, but see following. Stop grumbling Baz, your still alive and kicking so far. Age and illness doesn't define who we are, but more what we are able to do. Motto Do what I love doing, when I can until I can't. and dodging bullets in the meanwhile, too many bullets at moment.
Posts.Title: New battle to commence

Posts.Content: Well folks, No biopsy as yet as still waiting for a date. The consultant said there's no rush on the phone, hmmm but then started to talk about treatment options. Seems they have relied on the T3 MRI results which indicate it is contained but most definately interpreted as cancer. I said "aren't we getting ahead of ourselves as you don't know yet what type or grade it is", response no I Beleive it is far better to discuss options ahead of the biopsy result. I have 2 friends with PCa both were on HT and both had to come off due to dramatic is effects. Any opinion welcome Barry

Posts.Title: New battle to commence

Posts.Content: Chuck, Bob and Michael, Thanks, I threw that out knowing I didn't have a positive diagnosis yet, however I can't understand without biopsy results why my consultant urologist would open a potential treatment dialogue. This baffled me. My GP got a copy of the MRI report, from what he saw and the interpretation report, he Is firmly convinced the report is accurate. I also had a telephone call last Tuesday from the deputy medical director of my NHS Hospital, this was the call that caused some controversy when I got a letter last year advising I would get a call from the hospital at 13.30 April 7th 2015. She had done a thorough review of my file and was checking on the CRC, vascular etc and my current physical status. She was also surprised that a biopsy hadn't yet been done and would chase this up with a letter to the urology consultant copied to my GP. So as of now I'm in limbo, despite potential treatment options being raised and my GP being convinced. Good news is my GP is on the case and chasing up with the hospital. Isn't life a breeze. Barry

Posts.Title: New battle to commence

Posts.Content: I'll not enter into a litigation debate as there are far to many variables. I tend to agree with Spouse, One good thing in using the Internet it the ability to research the qualifications and experience of particular surgeons ( in the UK it's quite easy) , elsewhere I have no idea. I do know that I bothe researched the competency of both the surgeons that operated on me prior to letting them get anywhere near me. Fact, all surgical sites can be prone to herniation, particular abdominal. During pre surgery work up, the risks for every surgical procedure should be explained either verbally and/or written into the official patient acceptance forms. It would be highly unusual for this aspect to have been missed either specifically or generically. I don't think anyone on here can advise a course of action as this will be specific to your dads case. Hoping your dad is getting better and continues to do so. Barry

Posts.Title: considering sueing surgeon

Posts.Content: Fred, Not my forum as I'm on the CRC forum, but in the same situation as you, although your tests and mine are reversed. I started with a marginal PSA increase for my age at 5.2 last July, 6 months later after 2 months of antibiotics it went to 7.2. 2 months later a T3 MRI which indicates cancer confined, so now I'm due on the 5th May for a template 38 core biopsy. Seems you having 6 negative biopsies with increasing PSA values now a MRI this is the reverse procedure of what is done in the UK. As far as the PSA test results are concerned my limited understanding is that there can be a number of factors outside PCa that influence a increased PSA. There are many wise men on here who no doubt will give you far more detailed advice than I can. Good luck. Barry

I said "aren't we getting ahead of ourselves as you don't know yet what type or grade it is", response no I Beleive it is far better to discuss options ahead of the biopsy result. I have 2 friends with PCa both were on HT and both had to come off due to dramatic is effects. Any opinion welcome Barry
Posts.Signature: Diagnosed stage 3 March 011 Radical resection April 011 Restaged 2b April 011. 12/09 Colonoscopy clear but picked up hospital infection. Aorta & femoral arteries occluded. Clot buster drugs put me in ICU with internal bleeding. 9 blood units later they got it under control. Aortobifemoral surgery 5th May. yughh. PET scan indicates clear DEXA bone scan clear 13/5 CT showed "unknown" but no concern from docs. Inguinal lymph nodes and severe groin pain. Ultrasound and MRI show no nasties. Pheww Groin pain and enlarged lymph nodes still there. October -still the same pains but under semi control. Additional chest CT scan ordered for 11th November prior to surgery. Sinus surgery done and dusted. July 2014 PSA at 5.10. 2months of antibiotics in case of UTI, jan 2015 PSA at 7.20, 23/08 now 8.2, current 8.1 Prostate Cancer confirmed Gleason 3+Marginal 4. Active surveillance continues. PET CT Aug 2017 indicated lung nodule changes CT Guided biopsy 7/09 November 1 Vats Wedge section pathology Glomulated previous infection no Cancer. Posts.Title: New battle to commence

Posts.Content: Chuck, Bob and Michael, Thanks, I threw that out knowing I didn't have a positive diagnosis yet, however I can't understand without biopsy results why my consultant urologist would open a potential treatment dialogue. This baffled me. My GP got a copy of the MRI report, from what he saw and the interpretation report, he Is firmly convinced the report is accurate. I also had a telephone call last Tuesday from the deputy medical director of my NHS Hospital, this was the call that caused some controversy when I got a letter last year advising I would get a call from the hospital at 13.30 April 7th 2015. She had done a thorough review of my file and was checking on the CRC, vascular etc and my current physical status. She was also surprised that a biopsy hadn't yet been done and would chase this up with a letter to the urology consultant copied to my GP. So as of now I'm in limbo, despite potential treatment options being raised and my GP being convinced. Good news is my GP is on the case and chasing up with the hospital. Isn't life a breeze. Barry

Posts.Title: New battle to commence

Posts.Content: In itself an interesting synopsis in treating PCa in the older age range of which I am in this category. However, this must be pointed out that what MD Anderson state is the NORM, certainly within the UK it is. Patients are not considered old at the age of 70 these days in the UK NHS. Yes comorbid ailments are always seriously considered with regard to treatment options and this goes for ANY cancer or indeed non cancerous conditions. Its not rocket science that aggressive treatment where patients with comorbid conditions the treatment would in essence kill them or allow natural controlled progression. It is balancing medical treatment / intervention versus beneficial outcome. Who would be a doctor with thae daily decisions. To give an instance of what we always accept as the norm, contrast given for a CT scan can seriously affect kidney function and with patients who have renal impairment can result in that patient having to have lifetime dialysis. This is just one of the decisions doctors must take when balancing life saving need to detect what is are internal problems against possible future results of introducing contrast and the life of the patient.

Posts.Title: MD Andersons take on Aging and life expecctancy in Prostate Cancer Treatment

Posts.Content: Fred, Not my forum as I'm on the CRC forum, but in the same situation as you, although your tests and mine are reversed. I started with a marginal PSA increase for my age at 5.2 last July, 6 months later after 2 months of antibiotics it went to 7.2. 2 months later a T3 MRI which indicates cancer confined, so now I'm due on the 5th May for a template 38 core biopsy. Seems you having 6 negative biopsies with increasing PSA values now a MRI this is the reverse procedure of what is done in the UK. As far as the PSA test results are concerned my limited understanding is that there can be a number of factors outside PCa that influence a increased PSA. There are many wise men on here who no doubt will give you far more detailed advice than I can. Good luck. Barry

Posts.Content: The facts remains that most die with prostate cancer than from it. i shall endeavor as much as humanly possible the die with the former not from it. Seriously my GP's as well as my hospital continue to provide me with the confidence they take good care of me and I am honestly extremely at ease with how they look after me. Absolutely zero complaints from me. Dortunately I'm also not given to worrying to much as there is no point in making ones life more difficult than it already is. Barry

Posts.Title: New Uro and second opinion on pathology

Posts.Content: Joe, At least within th VA system being a Brit I'm guessing as I know zero as to how that system works, one would imagine you would be outside the world of insurance decisions ?. I know there is debate within the UK as whether low grade PCa (3+3 as a example should be radically treated. As my understanding goes more men die with PCa rather than from it. The reasoning is that with a quantum leap in diagnostics more are being diagnosed very early stage and IF Gleeson 6 (3+3) should in fact be treated at all. I am in this category and have surpisingly no concerns as I get frequent PSA tests which as a frankly rough indicator mine hovers between 5.8 to 7 ish. No doubt this debate will continue within the peer medical profession. Good luck and hope all works out for you. Barry

Posts.Title: MD Andersons take on Aging and life expecctancy in Prostate Cancer Treatment

Posts.Content: Steve, i can only echo what others have said, indeed you have had a unfortunate experience with drastic possible post procedure consequences. However, I cannot agree with you're statement to avoid a biopsy if at all possible. Unfortunately as of today a biopsy is the only reliable test available. Even my GP said "this is the most barbaric, inhuman procedure" yet it is the only method currently available. ive had two, the first a MRI templates biopsy with frankly little physical effect, the second TRUS had somewhat different effects, the procedure not comfortable I agree, yet 3 days later blue lighted into hospital with sepsis. At the results follow up the specialist didn't even mention it, the specialist urology sister said and I quote verbatim " I see you had a elevated temperature". One can imagine my response was " Elevated, that's somewhat of a understatement". One can conclude the sisters statement indicates how urology respond to post procedure sepsis, No big deal. As I'm on AS then in another 15 months I shall be having another one, does this thought worry me, no as it is for the sake of repetition the only method of producing a conclusive result, so be it. Im coming 73, so my views may change as age progresses. Meanwhile good luck and sincerely hope your problems resolve. Barry

Posts.Title: Help newbie need advice

Posts.Content: I've been living quite relaxed wth Gleason 3+3 nor for two and a half years on active surveillance. PSA started at 6 which was slightly high for my age, went to 7.2 then dropped back to 6.7. Recent 14 core TRUS which put me in hospital with sepsis bye the way showed only marginal increase of 1 core a marginal 4. Urologist offered me all options but said I quote " It will not shorten your life". Easy decision for me, I opted for continuing AS which the Uro agreed was the better course of action. Now will stay on 6 monthly PSA tests. I am more than comfortable and dare say relaxed and certainly I am not worried nor anxious and frankly never really think about it until the calendar warning on the IPad go is off a week before my next PSA. Its easy to get freaked out by hearing the word Cancer, I'm now living with a short short colon after 2 resections, another CT scan coming up due to symptoms returning. although I'm substantially older than yourself at 72 and a bit, I'd make one suggestion, freaking out doesn't achieve anything apart from making ones own and the families life a misery. Good luck and relax if you can. Barry

Posts.Title: 48 y/o Newbie

Posts.Content: Bricks, I'm no expert on prostate cancer as I'm on the CRC forum but also UK based, but a few things need explanation that's for sure. For our foreign members our NHS works differently to the US, as it is state provided we don't have the luxury of elective surgery or seeking a consultant unless it is under private health insurance and even this needs a referral from ones NHS GP. On another note, a close friend, he's a similar age to myself has had recurring prostate problems for a few months, his PSA was well in excess of 30 heading closer to 40 of I recall. Charles has all the tests over the last 3 months and finally they ruled out cancer, yet his PSA after 3 courses of antibiotics is still above 30. They don't want to operate on Charles unless it is essential and are trying a combination of drugs to see if they will work. If not he will have to have surgery, thankfully our local hospital is one of the few in the UK using the latest Da Vinci robotic surgical system. Ok your different to Charles as you have a confirmed diagnosis, but, his PSA is still in the 30's. I'm sure our other knowledgable members will chip in with answers as they pick up your thread. Nest wishes Barry

Posts.Title: Interesting how my GPs approach Prostate and other cancers

Posts.Content: Bricks, I'm no expert on prostate cancer as I'm on the CRC forum but also UK based, but a few things need explanation that's for sure. For our foreign members our NHS works differently to the US, as it is state provided we don't have the luxury of elective surgery or seeking a consultant unless it is under private health insurance and even this needs a referral from ones NHS GP. On another note, a close friend, he's a similar age to myself has had recurring prostate problems for a few months, his PSA was well in excess of 30 heading closer to 40 of I recall. Charles has all the tests over the last 3 months and finally they ruled out cancer, yet his PSA after 3 courses of antibiotics is still above 30. They don't want to operate on Charles unless it is essential and are trying a combination of drugs to see if they will work. If not he will have to have surgery, thankfully our local hospital is one of the few in the UK using the latest Da Vinci robotic surgical system. Ok your different to Charles as you have a confirmed diagnosis, but, his PSA is still in the 30's. I'm sure our other knowledgable members will chip in with answers as they pick up your thread. Nest wishes Barry
Posts.Signature: Diagnosed stage 3 March 011 Radical resection April 011 Restaged 2b April 011. 12/09 Colonoscopy clear but picked up hospital infection. Aorta & femoral arteries occluded. Clot buster drugs put me in ICU with internal bleeding. 9 blood units later they got it under control. Aortobifemoral surgery 5th May. yughh. PET scan indicates clear DEXA bone scan clear 13/5 CT showed "unknown" but no concern from docs. Inguinal lymph nodes and severe groin pain. Ultrasound and MRI show no nasties. Pheww Groin pain and enlarged lymph nodes still there. October -still the same pains but under semi control. Additional chest CT scan ordered for 11th November prior to surgery. Sinus surgery done and dusted. July 2014 PSA at 5.10. 2months of antibiotics in case of UTI, jan 2015 PSA at 7.20, 23/08 now 8.2, current 8.1 Prostate Cancer confirmed Gleason 3+Marginal 4. Active surveillance continues. PET CT Aug 2017 indicated lung nodule changes CT Guided biopsy 7/09 November 1 Vats Wedge section pathology Glomulated previous infection no Cancer. Not all's rosy in the garden, but see following. Stop grumbling Baz, your still alive and kicking so far. Age and illness doesn't define who we are, but more what we are able to do. Motto Do what I love doing, when I can until I can't. and dodging bullets in the meanwhile, too many bullets at moment.

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Content: Mikla, Just put me down as a whimp. I've had hundreds of needles, cannulas and IV's over the last few years to the point where the veins in my arms and back of hands have become so hard it is difficult to get a good sample. They are now considering for future blood tests having to go for a artery rather than a vein. Needles don't bother me in the least, however it is the thoughts alone that prompted my discussion. Colonoscopies I'm wide awake and although uncomfortable more than tolerable. Yes I'm a whimp and don't mind admitting to it. Barry

Posts.Title: What non-invasive testing should be considered before cystoscopy or biopsy?

Posts.Content: I'll let you know as I'm having tomorrow a MRI followed on 12th by the Doppler ultrasound. On Cipro for 2 months then at week 7 recheck the PSA. My interesting discussion with the urologist where they wanted to do a biopsy was If you want to stick needles through my anus and into the prostate then I want to know nothing about it. In other words unconscious. Reply These days it is not normally the way we do it. My reply This is my condition and I want an assurance. Begrudgingly I got it. They can give it as I said for colonoscopies and Esophigal why not prostate biopsies. He did weigh up what I said and noddded his head. So I'm on the learning curve with this as well. Barry

Posts.Title: What non-invasive testing should be considered before cystoscopy or biopsy?

Posts.Content: From a UK perspective, yes the incidence of prostate cancer has increased here, primarily the guru's state due to increased PSA testing backed by a long running government and NHS campaign called "Be Clear on Cancer". A decade before PCa was generally caught at a more advanced stage, whereas latterly most are diagnosed Fortuntely earlier due to the above and GP's being far more proactive in including PSA testing as a element of normal blood tests, certainly for those aged 50 and over. What is heartening is that governments of either persuasion over the last 15 years have actively promoted testing. barry

Posts.Title: questions about meds??

Posts.Content: Joe, "Peddling their trade" to me is apt terminology for what ostensibly in the US and other parts of the world is the private health systems funded by insurance and or funded research programmes on behalf of drug / equipment organizations. Here in the UK is quite different where yes we have private which accounts for less than 5% of the total number in the UK are treated. The remainder are treated under our National Health system which has a standard treatment regimen for each specific cancer type. These treatment regimes are reviewed by a multi disciplinary team (MDT) at each hospital in relation to each patient and that patients disease and condition. This is where we in the UK substantially differ from other countries as the treatment proposed or not is agreed by the "team" which encompasses every involved medical discipline and becomes specific for that patient. I have low grade PCa (Gleeson 3+ 3) and was offerred several treatment options from Watch and wait, through to prostactemy. After a 34 needle fusion biopsy a follow up T3 MRI, the consultant and his registrar sat with me and we discussed every option finally deciding on Active surveillance, a path for which I am perfectly happy with up to now. As you can see from my signature, I am not exactly without comorbid conditions, yet my personal findings are a contradiction to what you postulate. Im certainly not suggesting you are wrong but to draw an analogy, there are many shades of black and white as there are grey. it all I think comes down to to the individual preferences of the specialists and surgeons. Here our NHS doctors/ surgeons are allowed under contract to partially practice in the private medical industry, but and this is where our system differs substantially, our surgeons are restricted in their private practices to only charge what is termed the BUPA rate for an operation, in my colon cancer surgery my surgeon was paid 742 pounds sterling, the private anaesthetist got 438 pounds sterling, the thousands was taken by the private Hospital. That I think is the substantial difference. Barry

Posts.Title: MD Andersons take on Aging and life expecctancy in Prostate Cancer Treatment

Posts.Content: Just a question on Internet medications. In the Uk we have possibly one of the most controlled and regulated regimes for pharmaceuticals and yet there are so many cases where prescription drugs bought online are subsequently proved to be fake with all sorts of ingredients. I know we only pay the prescription value which is 6 pounds 70 pence at ant registered pharmacy, the drugs are free on the NHS. But having watched so many program's where the our NHS tracks down illicit drugs to find they are mostly fake and frankly contains so many harmful products, it would worry me buying online. Don't know what it's like in the US but over here the official sponge is don't buy. Maybe off topic a little but worth a mention. Barry

Posts.Title: It's behind me now

Posts.Content: Not wishing to butt in here but it is relative regarding the T3 MRI which I had done (in UK) 4 weeks previously. There were 2 consecutive scans, both with contrast, first the standard prostate and pelvic then a dynamic scan. Process lasted exactly 52 minutes, result being the interpretation was cancer. In the UK the standard practice is a T3 MRI, if no obvious cancer in the interpretation, no further action. If cancer is shown or suspected then a biopsy. In my case TRUS with a 38 core biopsy coming up under a general Anaesthetic. My PSA was 5.10 age 70 which is just above the upper threshold, 6 months later after a 2 month course of antibiotics it rose to7.2. My URO said that now they don't go for a biopsy unless the MRI reveals anything considered suspicious or nasty. He said without equivocation in his opinion less than 38 would not produce sufficient evidence as he regarded 6 or 12 core as superficial and opened the possibility of needing a second biopsy which in his words any prostate biopsy was essential but was the most barbaric procedure he could imagine. Therefore get it over and done with in one hit. So I'm now like you in the waiting phase before the procedure. Barry

Posts.Title: MP-MRI-US Fusion Targeted Biopsy

Posts.Content: Fred, Not my forum as I'm on the CRC forum, but in the same situation as you, although your tests and mine are reversed. I started with a marginal PSA increase for my age at 5.2 last July, 6 months later after 2 months of antibiotics it went to 7.2. 2 months later a T3 MRI which indicates cancer confined, so now I'm due on the 5th May for a template 38 core biopsy. Seems you having 6 negative biopsies with increasing PSA values now a MRI this is the reverse procedure of what is done in the UK. As far as the PSA test results are concerned my limited understanding is that there can be a number of factors outside PCa that influence a increased PSA. There are many wise men on here who no doubt will give you far more detailed advice than I can. Good luck. Barry

Posts.Title: What have been your experiences with new PHI test

Posts.Content: Maybe a point of discussion, but my perspective is its not relevant to this forum. We deal with recognised medical treatment protocols in treating any cancer. Does religion play a role in treatment and recovery I don't know, what I do know is that being focused, diligent and determined does play a role and this is derived from any belief we hold or more important our own self belief. Individually we cope with whatever life throws at us in different ways. That's my take, but I reiterate I would not wish to see the contents of this post progress into a fully open forum debate. It is all a matter of belief in whatever and individual perspective. Let's leave it at that please. Barry

Posts.Title: Spam in my pm box

Posts.Content: Denis, Although I'm in the UK and having a very similar score as yourself in detailed discussion twice in the last two years the Uro and team agreed that AS was the best course of action. The key words used by the Uro based on the latest compararitive TRUS results were "Your cancer will not shorten your life". I am content and quite happy with continuing AS until things change, just had the latest 3 monthly blood test today. So for me until a day before the calendar reminder for the blood test it does not enter my mind. Hoping the decision you have reached sits as comfortably with you as it does for myself. Barry

Posts.Title: New Uro and second opinion on pathology

Posts.Content: Maybe things are a little different over the pond in Blighty, screening as well as AS is not age related at this time, yet I am sure given the overwhelming demands on the NHS some form of rationing will be introduced. Some suggest a unwritten and unpublisized age cut off date exists at 72, true or not I can’t say. Thankfully they haven’t let up on myself, indeed at coming up to 74 our NHS and particularly my hospital I’d suggest are being more “active” with myself. PSA spiked this month to 11.2 from 8.2 in January, one could suggest at my age of 73 that’s a remarkable rise in 4 months. Response from Urology was immediate, contact us Monday. The age debate may and will no doubt roll on. My two pennies worth is, simple Baseline PSA at 50 for everyone then, dependent on the initial result a monitoring frequency should be established. After all breast cancer screening in the U.K. has been championed for over 20 years by the NHS and has increased significantly the % or early detection. Perhaps it is time as some suggest that males are given the same equality with PCa testing. Barry

Posts.Title: Looks like old guys over 70 do not have to worry about death from PC

Posts.Content: Bricks, I'm no expert on prostate cancer as I'm on the CRC forum but also UK based, but a few things need explanation that's for sure. For our foreign members our NHS works differently to the US, as it is state provided we don't have the luxury of elective surgery or seeking a consultant unless it is under private health insurance and even this needs a referral from ones NHS GP. On another note, a close friend, he's a similar age to myself has had recurring prostate problems for a few months, his PSA was well in excess of 30 heading closer to 40 of I recall. Charles has all the tests over the last 3 months and finally they ruled out cancer, yet his PSA after 3 courses of antibiotics is still above 30. They don't want to operate on Charles unless it is essential and are trying a combination of drugs to see if they will work. If not he will have to have surgery, thankfully our local hospital is one of the few in the UK using the latest Da Vinci robotic surgical system. Ok your different to Charles as you have a confirmed diagnosis, but, his PSA is still in the 30's. I'm sure our other knowledgable members will chip in with answers as they pick up your thread. Nest wishes Barry

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Content: First of all, potential infection risk factors are dictated by the type of biopsy. TRUS has the highest factor as they puncture the inner anal wall, as everyone knows even with a completely successful pre bowel prep your passage is contaminated. Hence this has the highest infection factor. This put me blue lighted into hospital for 3 days with sepsis. Being philosophical and with my luck I was shall we say prepared I'd fall into the (in the UK) up to 3%. Barry

Posts.Title: Interesting how my GPs approach Prostate and other cancers

Posts.Content: Southampton General University Hospital has just released a publication following trials on more than 200 patients of a day case procedure to reduce the size of the prostate. The procedure involves placing microscopic beads in the arteries that feed blood to the prostate which coagulate and block blood flow to the prostate resulting in a dramatic reduction in size and volume. The same principle and procedure of placing stents or clearing blockages in the main arteries is used where a incision is made in the right groin to access the femoral artery. A catheter is placed and guided wire placement of the beads is made In some patients there is a possibility that a incision is needed in left groin to complete the procedure. Normally the time spent in the intervention suite is 1 to 2 hours, followed by recovery for up to 6 hours on the day ward. In nearly all cases the patient was released from hospital the same day. A separate study is running in parallel to identify what effect this procedure may have on prostate tumours as one researcher said, that a zero blood supply could inhibit tumour growth but qualified that this research is in the very early stage. Obviously it was stated that this procedure would normally be offered to those that had reached the age of 60 and above, but was also an option to younger patients after extensive discussion. The results so far have seen a dramatic improvement in nearly all patients with no problem with erectile disfunctional and a major improvement in urinary response. They say it is a major step forward as there is no need for invasive surgery. Barry

Posts.Title: New Procedure for Enlarged Prostate

Posts.Content: I've been living quite relaxed wth Gleason 3+3 nor for two and a half years on active surveillance. PSA started at 6 which was slightly high for my age, went to 7.2 then dropped back to 6.7. Recent 14 core TRUS which put me in hospital with sepsis bye the way showed only marginal increase of 1 core a marginal 4. Urologist offered me all options but said I quote " It will not shorten your life". Easy decision for me, I opted for continuing AS which the Uro agreed was the better course of action. Now will stay on 6 monthly PSA tests. I am more than comfortable and dare say relaxed and certainly I am not worried nor anxious and frankly never really think about it until the calendar warning on the IPad go is off a week before my next PSA. Its easy to get freaked out by hearing the word Cancer, I'm now living with a short short colon after 2 resections, another CT scan coming up due to symptoms returning. although I'm substantially older than yourself at 72 and a bit, I'd make one suggestion, freaking out doesn't achieve anything apart from making ones own and the families life a misery. Good luck and relax if you can. Barry

Posts.Title: 48 y/o Newbie

Posts.Content: At our PPG meeting last evening I asked what criteria our doctors used before a referral to specialists is made as well as statistics for early, late or indeed terminal prognosis. With a patient base of over 13,000 and 8 GP’s their work load is high to say the least. The answer was enlightening They refer to specialists anyone assessed at more than a 3% possibility of having PCa or indeed any other cancer. This seems to be a low theshold, however judged from previous history, current symptoms as well as physical examination and or current test results. To me this appears to indicate a high percentage of referrals if the benchmark is set at 3% possibility of cancer. Waitimg for the stats on referrals to confirmed cancer diagnosis which has to be correlated, yet I would suggest our GP practice is very proactive. After nearly 3 years of being on AS where my PSA has risen from 5.2 to very recently 11.1 the possibility of intervention has increased, yet my eminent Uro suggests wait 3 months and do another PSA. Is this proposal concerning, personally not in the least given both my doctors and specialists are so on the case so to speak. The rider is I do have a follow up with the specialist on the 30th so we shall see what is proposed. Meanwhile I shall sleep comfortable in the knowledge im being well monitored. No need for stress, anxiety or indeed panic Barry
