Posts.Title: Interesting how my GPs approach Prostate and other cancers

Posts.Content: An attempt to clarify, Asking Do the practice have stats on referrals for cancer. (All Cancers) That show a) Early stage b) Late stage c) Terminal stage The above question was made to the practice GP representatives on the committee at the request of 4 cancer patients who are direct surgery patients. The answer was Any patient who is evaluated to be at risk of having cancer being 3 % is referrred. The patient base is 13,200, confirmed with a cancer diagnosis(All Cancer) is 3.4%. Sense or no sense to me is irrelevant, what this indicates to myself and other committee members is our doctors are very proactive and action refererralz for cancer investigation for those evaluated as having the possibility. Note of interest The formulae for practice funding from NHS England through Local clinical commissioning groups is based on demographics. The poorer the area the higher the patient payment to the practice Where we reside is classified as predominately professional, young to middle age couples with young families the practice is given substantially less than a equivalent practice in a termed impoverished area. 13,200 patients, the practice is given funding per head for 10,000 whereas a practice in a impoverished locale receives the full per head funding. Therefor they have to do more with less cash. Barry

Posts.Title: Interesting how my GPs approach Prostate and other cancers

Posts.Content: From a UK perspective, yes the incidence of prostate cancer has increased here, primarily the guru's state due to increased PSA testing backed by a long running government and NHS campaign called "Be Clear on Cancer". A decade before PCa was generally caught at a more advanced stage, whereas latterly most are diagnosed Fortuntely earlier due to the above and GP's being far more proactive in including PSA testing as a element of normal blood tests, certainly for those aged 50 and over. What is heartening is that governments of either persuasion over the last 15 years have actively promoted testing. barry

Posts.Title: Family

Posts.Content: myrtha, sorry to read your post. two things Do you mean Prostate Cancer Or Bowel Cancer Or Both Unusual to hear of prostate cancer penetrating the lower bowel. There are numerous types of pain medication, but a warning IF it is bowel (Colon Cancer) until he is surgically treated if this is the plan, be careful of using opiate based pain medication as if used in high doses this could stop the bowel working. Barry

Posts.Title: Need help-URGENT!!!

Posts.Content: Good laugh at that. Couple of months back grandson Jake who's autistic is in with the senior GP at our practice as his mom and doc are discussing Jakies ongoing weight (or lack of) and behaviour problems as he's on so many different meds prescribed by different specialists. Jake aapparently (well as usual) totally ignores what's going on around him and is engrossed in the screen of his life (IPad mini) when without warning he says to the doc, " Your a masochist" . doc says I have been called a lot worse than that Jake. Jake looks at him and said, I will say a lot worse the next time, but I can't think of anything else just now. Then his head is back down on the Emma wishes the floor would open, Doc shakes hi head and smiles and says, I'm sure he will. Emma says she couldn't get out fast enough. Kids.

Posts.Title: A Little Humor - Kids Say the Darndest Things

Posts.Content: Being on the sidelines with PCa (3+ marginal 4) and on AS for over 3 years as well as having 2 episodes of CRC perhaps I look at things a little differently to many. Frankly PCa never enters my thoughts apart from remembering my 6 monthly PSA check which precedes the meeting with the URO. I simply could not live my life constantly thinking of what may occur, far better for me to concentrate on what actually matters. There are those that become obsessed with their diagnosis or treatment which pervades every day thoughts marginalising the redeeming aspects of what life is. Granted diagnosis and treatment can be at best extremely disturbing and difficult yet having had two major episodes with CRC and living with PCa tends for myself to focus my mind on the positive aspects of life. We all deal with the pitfalls of life differently, I prefer to live looking at the positives rather than the negatives and doing what I like and love doing. for certain not one of us can evade mortality, something obviously I wish to delay for as long as possible and living in a dark place frankly does not sit well with me. I agree with what all have said, I reiterate I choose life over fear. Barry

Posts.Title: Choose life over fear

Posts.Content: mdt, Sorry you are having these problems. Although I'm on the CRC forum I was diagnosed with prostate cancer some 3 years ago and in between a recurrence of colon cancer. So one may say I should be one of the eternal worriers am I, not in the least. Most of us will die with prostate cancer, not from having it. Thats a fact. PCa appears to be the latest high percentage forum input, mainly I suggest due to the advancement in using PSA blood tests as well as diagnostic techniques and our personal knowledge. Google can be a great tool for specifics, but the devil in disguise with generalised medical symptoms. Rather than research procedures as well as general symptoms I would suggest you have convinced yourself ahead of a biopsy or MRI. i was offered all treatment options should I elect to have treatment Or and in conjunction with my Uro we agreed that active surveillance was the way to go with 6 monthly blood tests and 18 month to 2 years 3T MRI and biopsies dictated by PSA level as well MRI results. Im quite content to follow this regime as it does not cause me symptoms nor any concerns (Worry). My Uro's suggest that some can live with PCa with no worries or anxiety whilst others find it difficult to live with their diagnosis and wish to go straight into treatment. Thats about it frankly, my input is worth exactly what you paid for it, nothing. Wish you the best outcome from your biopsy. Barry

Posts.Title: 14 month post - op status

Posts.Content: Jeepers creepers, and I thought I had been taken to the cleaners for a colon resection and 4 days in a private hospital in the UK at 13,000 pounds. Let's say 20k in dollars. For a internal clipper that retails in the US for 146 dollars their charge was 1206. Each bag of saline was 9.26 pounds pence, the same costs in the NHS 46 pence. Dont know how you guys and gals do this insurance business every time. Thank God we have the NHS warts and all. Barry

Sinus surgery done and dusted. July 2014 PSA at 5.10. 2months of antibiotics in case of UTI, jan 2015 PSA at 7.20, 23/08 now 8.2, current 8.1 Prostate Cancer confirmed Gleason 3+Marginal 4. Posts.Title: Come on Man!!

Posts.Content: Not suggesting anything said is wrong, but I'm appalled if this is how the US system works. As I was self funding for my resection (that's another set of facts that forced me to go private) surgeons and Anaestetist charges are fixed under a BUPA scale as to what they can charge. Outof the 13,000 pounds the surgeons maximum charge was 742 pounds and the Anaestetist was 450 on the BUPA scale. The rest was 550 pounds a day for the bed (room) 2110 per day for 2 nights in recovery and anything else they could think of to increase the charges. 4 days later my surgeon moved me by private ambulance to the NHS hospital where he worked to I quote "so I can keep an eye on you". I never found out who paid for the private ambulance, it sure wasn't me. Im guessing that with the unsustainable demands on our NHS some form of insurance will be introduced in the near future. At our GP surgeries the first question asked is "do you have private insurance" which tells me we are heading down the same road as the US. Barry

Posts.Title: Come on Man!!

Posts.Content: Jeepers creepers, and I thought I had been taken to the cleaners for a colon resection and 4 days in a private hospital in the UK at 13,000 pounds. Let's say 20k in dollars. For a internal clipper that retails in the US for 146 dollars their charge was 1206. Each bag of saline was 9.26 pounds pence, the same costs in the NHS 46 pence. Dont know how you guys and gals do this insurance business every time. Thank God we have the NHS warts and all. Barry

Posts.Title: Nearing the end of active surveillance

Posts.Content: I too am surprised as I’ve is at the apparent rapid move to surgical treatment, unless of course there are underlying factors. To put things into perspective, assuming I am considerably older than yourself have been on AS for over 4 years starting with a PSA of 5.1 if I recall correctly which has increased to 11.2. Next PSA check is May, Yet in the 4 years I have never and I mean never lived with the thoughts of a ticking bomb. Indeed I never think about it until the calendar reminds me another blood test is due. i don’t often visit the PCa forum but I am always amazed where I read a infintismal percentile increase raises so much anxiety. i Fortunately am under two fantastic Urologists, both have assured me that PCa will not kill me. I am comfortable remaining on AS and more than comfortable with their prediction. All I can echo is Good luck Barry

Posts.Title: Fear is a liar

Posts.Content: No I don’t think they are giving you BS, testimony is this. There are many on here and thousands off forum who have been in just as dire a situation as you appear to suggest and are still alive. Honestly I do not think any doctor would deliberately feed a patient BS and if so that is completely immoral and contradicts the oath they all have to swear and live by in their profession. They may be conservative at times with fact, but misleading a patient I doubt it. Good look and hope you prove you’re doctor right. Barry

Posts.Title: Am I getting the truth

PatientDecided.Sample: The key phrase used was "it will most definitely not shorten you're life". So rather than rush in with any of the interventions, surgery, radiotherapy, seeds, HT we jointly elected to continue AS with 3 monthly PSA testing....
